displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Yeah, I guess. Doctor: So, I’ll print out the phase one and I’ll print out the immune therapy one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, those are two sort of, uh, things that you can be taking home and reading. Patient: Right. Doctor: I would stay with the current treatment for now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because I need to check, if that, that we were to move you to, let’s say your AR-V7 was positive - Patient: Right. Doctor: They may want you to stay on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Or we could stop the TGF-A drug.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: -and for that immunotherapy six hundred thousand dollars. So Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: We’re trying not to let the insurance companies … for a different indication and insurance companies… Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: you have five FDA approved therapies. (xx) Patient: Okay. I wanna discuss with Dr. L___ who is my oncolgoist said I should really Doctor: I communicate with her, etcetera notes, translated to him real time so to speak. Patient: Okay. I understand that you’re Doctor: see in the notes Patient: Um I did a couple of months ago. Yeah because I did something PSA… Doctor: Okay. And did you plans in the future?

Patient: I know, I, yeah, no, I’d like to go and see if I have it or not because that would be another option I could possibly go to Europe or wherever and have them do it, if I know it’s going to help. If it’s not going to help, I don’t want to go over there. Doctor: No. I agree. So, but that would mean you would sign up for the study if they’re going to do the scan. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So you’re okay with that? Patient: Yeah. Yeas. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Uh, there’s no penalty if I don’t, is there? Doctor: If you don’t go on-? Patient: If I do go there and don’t go on it? Where, where will I get the shots at if I um stay here? Doctor: Here. Patient: Oh, here? Doctor: Yes. In the hospital. You just, uh, or downstairs in radiation, sorry.

Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial. Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner.

Patient: Put you in a hotel? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Hum. And that’s in what town? Doctor: No. I’ll tell you. I can find out. (Laughs) Patient: There’s no way, there’s no way of getting that? What medicine is that they give you for it? Doctor: It’s not the medicine. It’s the scan that is a specific one. That scanner is not available here or around here. Family Member: The scan will detect-? Doctor: If you have the PSMA. If you have that antigen or not in your cells. Then that will help us decide whether we put you on the study or not. Patient: And you can’t get it here in the states? Doctor: Not yet. Family Member: The scan. Doctor: The scan you can get.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: And I’ll… Doctor: And today - you had blood work today though? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So we should be able to give you a PSA from that by tomorrow or the next day or two. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah so I’m thinking I can see you back in three months. In between at some point, about half way six weeks or so, I do want to repeat PSA. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And can you get it up there? Patient: I’ll get it from C___. Doctor: Okay. Do you need a script from me? Patient: Yeah, I better. Doctor: Okay. That way it’s a reminder that you need to go get that.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So again, you have my blessing, so to speak, but I would also like a second person’s approval as well. Patient: Right. Doctor: Given the primary care provider who’s known you for a long time Patient: Right. Yeah, share it with my primary care, Dr____. Doctor: Now your PSA level from two weeks ago, I think it was third. Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah. Doctor: Was at zero point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay, so that’s very good news because it’s a very slight - Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it was zero point three. The time before that it was like two months before and went from point three to point five. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: Okay. So as in one day you get the chemo, the second day you come in and just get that shot. Patient: Okay. I think that’s what B do. A friend of mine, I think that’s what he get. Patient: He doesn’t get a shot or nothing. Doctor: The second day? Patient: No he said it was come - I think he said it was come three times, twice, twice a month. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Something like that. Doctor: Oh I see. Okay. Patient: See he says three… Doctor: Okay so not uh. Now the other possibility is of diarrhea. So you know if you do have it we’ll need to control it, give you lomotil, give you medication to help control Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that would be great! If, you know, uh, we don’t see it - more, it is a zero. The testosterone has recovered. That would be ideal. Um. The next step is, you know, that we don’t get rid of your cancer with all of this and that your PSA goes up in the future. And, is that a longer time to get to that point or is it sort of like, even if we just did one thing, it’s all on-time? Patient: I do have one question. The, the rib. (pause) Doctor: Uh, because, we, we don’t normally cut out the ribs. I mean, that’s where we’re gonna offer radiation to that spot. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, that’s gonna treat that spot. Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles. Doctor: So, right. So, we start the hormones. We get you chemotherapy. We give you a little bit of a break. I don’t know if it’s a month- Healthcare Professional: Mm Hmm. Doctor: And then you have your surgery. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then, based on what we see under the microscope, they can discern whether or not we’re gonna give you radiation to your prostate to try to clean up the area or is it all pretty decent. And, then they can plan the spot radiation to the sites that we’ve seen before. (pause) Patient: Yeah, it was a lymph node and

Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing? Doctor: Yeah. Like, but if you’re fifty. That’s not in line with what I think is happening. You should level off with this stuff. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: It should come back down to like a seven or eight or whatever? Doctor: Yeah. Or even if it stays ten forever. I don’t care. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I don’t want it to go to a hundred because then I’d feel like, uh-oh, maybe somethings going on.

Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah so if you call and say hey who’s out there with uh you know at the R___ Branch, um… Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s - there’s many, there’s many, but they literally are all good. Patient: I want to get – I not only want to get that but I would like to get one that does further and maybe practices in W____ … Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: …and operates out of the uh works out of the uh W____ location. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Makes it easier for us. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know your numbers always suggest that you’re dry. You know like you’re just a tad dehydrated. It always runs a little high. The other number we check is the B.U.N. or the bun.

Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. Doctor: You know kind of maybe just don't want to hang there. You know, they're not sick all the time. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her. Patient: Uh I try not to do that. Family Member 1: Yeah. What about using their toilet? See what I’m saying, while he’s there. Doctor: So same thing, I would just bring a pair of gloves, your own towels and then you wipe and just get a bag that you throw off the stuff. You know what's hard is toddlers get into everything. And you just can't help it. They're curious. Family Member 1: Well, it wouldn't be just for the toddler. Like we all use the main bathroom. There's the upstairs. She's still in diapers, so she has where she not trained yet. Okay, but myself the one that you come in the door, I can't keep climbing the stairs and using the bathroom. Right? And that he has to discipline he still has to disinfect, right? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. So you you get one of those Clorox thingy that you pull out. Patient: Yeah. I know.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That also tells you about chemo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The vitamin C part would only be done here. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, so, that would be, letting you go through that process to sort of say, “Okay. That’s the more traditional next step.” Um. The other one is a window phase one. Is that you have therapy, you’re not ready to go to chemotherapy, I’m willing to try something under our observations with blood tests and scans. That if the cancer would sort of wildly changing, we abort and do chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. But, some folks, everything we know about the drugs you’ve had so far, we’ve had people gamble at one point. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. That maybe that you say in what you’re doing now, and if you are AR-V7 positive, then we can sort of say, “Hey, yeah, let’s look at this other option,” if the immune therapy would be something that you would think about. Patient: Okay. What, what, what’s the, uh, uh, um likelihood of, of, if at that time the AR-V7, uh, testing comes back negative which means I can’t do that. Doctor: Right.

Patient: Tired. Doctor: Tired? How about the diarrhea stuff? Did it happen again? Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: After the last chemo? Okay. Let me take a look at your belly. Patient: mumbling (sound of door) Doctor: Here I’ll take that. Remember to take it okay with you. Oh! Careful. Don’t lean on that chair. Patient: Ow! Doctor: That’s the same (speaking softly) Patient: No. Patient: Awww. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay so and you had quite a bit of this current chemotherapy that you’ve been on. Okay so we’ve given you about twelve cycles, but the good thing is it has worked and has kept the cancer in check all this time. The other good thing is that I didn’t see any other new areas. So the lung, liver, none of those were involved. Patient: Okay.
